image.altText: An overview of Parliament house showing both sides of the senate

items.synopsis: The Senate votes in favour of the Voice to Parliament legislation, finalising the form of the referendum.

title.children: Referendum legislation passes parliament, putting Australia on track for Voice vote

image.altText: Albanese stands speaking to media from a courtyard.

items.synopsis: The federal government has suffered its first major defeat in the Senate, with the Greens and Coalition uniting to reject Labor's centrepiece housing policy.

title.children: Government gains early election trigger as Senate rejects housing bill

image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

items.synopsis: PwC confirms it has been affected by the MOVEit Transfer cyber hack, while the Australian dollar is closing in on 70 US cents as another RBA rate rise is considered a done deal. Follow the latest financial news and analysis on our markets live blog.

title.children: PwC caught up in global data breach, Aussie dollar closes in on 70 US cents, ASX opens higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PwC is just the latest global firm to disclose that they have been impacted by the MOVEit Transfer software. Last week, the US Department of Energy and other federal agencies were affected through the file transfer software, while other global companies including Shell, British Airways and the BBC have also fallen victim to the attack. Hackers used a flaw in the MOVEit software to gain access to confidential data, but the Russian-linked group who had previously claimed responsibility hasn't commented on the US or PwC hacks. You can read more about the US federal agencies which have been affected by the hack below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC isn't the only global company caught up in the MOVEit hack

featuredLink.title: US energy department, other federal agencies hit in global hacking spree

children.content: PwC is just the latest global firm to disclose that they have been impacted by the MOVEit Transfer software.

Last week, the US Department of Energy and other federal agencies were affected through the file transfer software, while other global companies including Shell, British Airways and the BBC have also fallen victim to the attack.
Hackers used a flaw in the MOVEit software to gain access to confidential data, but the Russian-linked group who had previously claimed responsibility hasn't commented on the US or PwC hacks.
You can read more about the US federal agencies which have been affected by the hack below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has built on its modest early gains, and now looks set to match or exceed Friday's Wall Street gains. The ASX 200 index is up 0.5% at 7,288 points, with the broader All Ordinaries rising 0.4% to 7,483. The healthcare and biotech sector is dominating the gains, with Polynovo, CSL and Fisher and Paykel Healthcare all among the top 10 gains. A 2.5% surge for Woolworths was also boosting the broader market. The resource sectors were the major drags, with both mining and energy losing ground. Top five gains: Abacus Property Group: +6.8% to $2.755 Star Entertainment: +5.2% to $1.105 Domino's Pizza: +2.9% to $45.17 Johns Lyng: +2.9% to $5.99 Polynovo: +2.7% to $1.545 Bottom five losses: Lake Resources: -15.3% to $0.4025 Syrah Resources: -5.2% to $0.8625 Liontown Resources: -5.1% to $2.99 New Hope Corporation: -4.7% to $5.46 Chalice Mining: -4.2% to $6.79
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX extends gains at midday

children.content: The Australian share market has built on its modest early gains, and now looks set to match or exceed Friday's Wall Street gains.
The
ASX 200 index is up 0.5% at 7,288 points
, with the broader
All Ordinaries rising 0.4% to 7,483
The healthcare and biotech sector is dominating the gains, with
Polynovo, CSL and Fisher and Paykel Healthcare
all among the top 10 gains.
A
2.5% surge for Woolworths
was also boosting the broader market.
The resource sectors were the major drags, with
both mining and energy losing ground
Top five gains:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As if PwC did not have enough of its own problems, news has broken that the consulting and accountancy firm is one of hundreds of organisations to be affected by a major cyber hack. PwC has just released a statement saying the impact on it is relatively minor and few of its clients are affected. "We are aware that MOVEit, a third party transfer platform, has experienced a cybersecurity incident which has impacted hundreds of organisations including PwC. PwC uses the software with a limited number of client engagements. "As soon as we learned of this incident we stopped using the platform and started our own investigation. "Our investigation has shown that PwC's own IT network has not been compromised and that MOVEit's vulnerability had a limited impact on PwC. We have reached out to the small number of clients whose files were impacted to discuss the incident. "Data security is a key priority for PwC and we continue to put the right resources and safeguards in place to protect our network." It never rains but it pours. For more on the MOVEit hack, ABC News and Reuters had this story on Friday evening.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC caught up in global cyber hack

featuredLink.title: US energy department, other federal agencies hit in global hacking spree

children.content: As if PwC did not have enough of its own problems, news has broken that the consulting and accountancy firm is one of hundreds of organisations to be affected by a major cyber hack.
PwC has just released a statement
saying the impact on it is relatively minor and few of its clients are affected.
"We are aware that
MOVEit, a third party transfer platform
, has experienced a cybersecurity incident which has impacted hundreds of organisations including PwC.
PwC uses the software with a limited number of client engagements
"As soon as we learned of this incident we stopped using the platform and started our own investigation.
"Our investigation has shown that
PwC's own IT network has not been compromised
and that MOVEit's vulnerability had a limited impact on PwC. We have reached out to the small number of clients whose files were impacted to discuss the incident.
"Data security is a key priority for PwC and we continue to put the right resources and safeguards in place to protect our network."
It never rains but it pours.
For
more on the MOVEit hack, ABC News and Reuters
had this story on Friday evening.
